text: - [Instructor] Let's get started
with CodeWhisperer individuals
using Visual Studio and the AWS Toolkit.
Go to the Manage Extension window.
Search for AWS Toolkit.
It will be the first answer.
Click on the Download button.
Once the toolkit is downloaded,

you have to restart your
Visual Studio instance
so that setup can install the toolkit.
Click on Modify.
Once the setup has completed the install,
you may restart Visual Studio.
Open the Extension menu,
now you get to AWS toolkit,
and click on Getting Started.
Select Amazon CodeWhisperer.
You are using CodeWhisperer on your own,
so click on the Sign up or Sign in button.

To do so, you will have to
log in with an AWS Builder ID.

To proceed, click on the
Open and Copy Code button.

It leads you to a webpage
where you can paste the code
and start the authentication process.
If you don't have an AWS Builder ID yet,
you can simply create one
by entering your personal email address,
and click Next.
You enter your name, here, AWS Toolkit.

Then, you paste the code
you've received by email.
Now, define your password

and allow the AWS Toolkit
key to access your profile.
That's it, you're logged in.
Let's move back to the Program.cs file.
If you click on the CodeWhisperer icon
at the bottom of the editor view,
you access the CodeWhisperer menu.
Let's write a piece of code

that calculate the 10
first Fibonacci numbers.
As you can see,

CodeWhisperer provides
comment and code suggestion.

It can provide code
suggestion line by line,
or by code block.
That's it, you've just started
with CodeWhisperer individuals.
